thread.title: Same sad story as Reds' skid reaches 11 games
thread.title_full: Same sad story as Reds' skid reaches 11 games

title: Same sad story as Reds' skid reaches 11 games
text:
Same sad story as Reds' skid reaches 11 games John Fay , jfay@enquirer.com 11:06 p.m. EDT September 30, 2015 Tyler Holt, right, is congratulated by Adam Duvall after scoring in the first inning. Kareem Elgazzar Reds manager Bryan Price laughs as heads back to the dugout before the first inning. Sam Greene Reds third baseman Todd Frazier laughs with TV crew members as he heads back to the dugout before the first inning. Sam Greene Reds starter Anthony DeSclafani delivers to the plate in the first inning. Kareem Elgazzar Reds center fielder Tyler Holt singles to right field in the bottom of the first inning. Kareem Elgazzar Brandon Phillips singles in the first inning. Kareem Elgazzar Tyler Holt (40) scores on a sacrifice fly by Jay Bruce in the first inning. Kareem Elgazzar Tyler Holt is congratulated in the dugout after scoring in the first inning. Kareem Elgazzar Brayan Pena doubles to center field in the second inning. Sam Greene Brayan Pena reaches over the plate to double in the second inning. Kareem Elgazzar Brayan Pena slides safely into second base. Kareem Elgazzar Reds catcher Brayan Pena blocks the plate as Cubs left fielder Kyle Schwarber scores in the third inning. Kareem Elgazzar Cubs fans cheer on their team after Chicago Cubs right fielder Austin Jackson hits a two-run double in the third inning. Sam Greene Reds shortstop Eugenio Suarez plays a ground ball off the bat of Cubs right fielder Jorge Soler in the fourth inning. Sam Greene Reds shortstop Eugenio Suarez makes a throw for a double play in the fourth inning. Sam Greene Reds second baseman Brandon Phillips catches a throw as Addison Russell slides safely into second in the fourth inning. Sam Greene Reds starting pitcher Anthony DeSclafani yells into his glove as he comes off the mound following the fourth inning. Sam Greene Reds starting pitcher Anthony DeSclafani sits in the dugout between innings. Kareem Elgazzar Reds pitcher Jon Moscot sits in the dugout between innings. Kareem Elgazzar Reds third baseman Todd Frazier, who was not in the starting lineup, sits in the dugout between innings. The Enquirer/Kareem Elgazzar Brandon Phillips throws to first on a double play attempt in the sixth inning. Kareem Elgazzar Jay Bruce flies out to right in the bottom of the seventh. Sam Greene Cubs left fielder Kyle Schwarber (12) fields a fly ball off the bat of Jay Bruce in the bottom of the seventh inning. Sam Greene Cubs left fielder Kyle Schwarber throws a ball to the fans as the Cubs return to the dugout after the bottom of the seventh. Sam Greene Brandon Phillips fields a grounder in the seventh inning. The Enquirer/Kareem Elgazzar Eugenio Suarez dives after a ground ball in the top of the eighth inning. Sam Greene Tony Cingrani slides into the base path attempting to field a bunt off the bat of Addison Russell in the top of the eighth. Sam Greene Tony Cingrani delivers in the eighth inning. Kareem Elgazzar Tony Cingrani bobbles the ball as it's returned to him after giving up a two-run single to Austin Jackson in the top of the eighth. Sam Greene Brandon Phillips looks frustrated after the Cubs scored on an Addison Russell double in the top of the ninth inning. Sam Greene Collin Balester delivers a pitch in the top of the ninth inning. Sam Greene Jay Bruce follows through on a sacrifice fly in the bottom of the ninth. Sam Greene Reds manager Bryan Price, left, gives Cincinnati Reds relief pitcher Ryan Mattheus the ball in the eighth inning. Kareem Elgazzar Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Reds shortstop Eugenio Suarez plays a ground ball off the bat of Cubs right fielder Jorge Soler in the fourth inning. (Photo: Sam Greene) 32 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN 4 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
The way Anthony DeSclafani started Wednesday and the way the he finished may have indicated that his innings load was catching up to him. 
DeSclafani , in the his final start of the season, took the loss as the Reds fell to the Chicago Cubs 10-3 Wednesday night before a crowd of 21,397 at Great American Ball Park. 
Box score: Cubs 10, Reds 3 
The loss was the 11 th straight for the Reds – their longest skid since 1998. They haven't lost 12 in a row since 1993. 
"It doesn't even look like baseball right now as ugly as these games are," Reds manager Bryan Price said. "We're behind early. We're not scoring runs. We're playing against teams that are excited to be in the postseason. We're just finishing out our year." 
DeSclafani retired the first eight batters he faced. Then 10 of the last 18 batters he faced reached, eight by hit and two by walk. DeSclafani went five-plus innings and allowed five runs on eight hits. He walked two and struck out eight. 
DeSclafani finishes the year 9-13 with a 4.05 ERA. He threw a career-high 184 1/3 innings. He threw 136 1/3 last year, plus 27 in the Arizona Fall League. 
He faded in his last four starts, allowing 17 runs on 25 hits over 15 2/3 innings. That took his ERA from 3.67 to 4.05. 
Price was pleased with DeSclafani's season. 
"What am going to say about this kid?" Price said. "He's kind of been the saving grace for this staff. It certainly wasn't the type of game he wanted to have to finish the season. In the end, the kid topped 180 innings, he pitched all the way through. He made all his starts. And we think the world of this guy." 
DeSclafani was pleased with his season – well, except the end of it. 
"I guess it was good season overall," DeSclafani said. "I'm definitely disappointed the way I ended it. It's not the ending I had in mind. I had a couple of goals that I wanted to reach that I didn't reach. 
"It's definitely going to leave a sour taste in my mouth going into the offseason . It's going to make me work harder." Joey Votto, Todd Frazier out of the lineup 
The Reds got off to a good start for the first time in days. DeSclafani struck out the side in the first. It was the first time in four games that the Reds did not allow a run in the first inning. 
Center fielder Tyler Holt singled in his first at-bat as a Red. Brandon Phillips followed with a blooper down the right-field line that dropped for a double. 
Jay Bruce hit one to deep center for a sacrifice fly to give the Reds a 1-0 lead. It was their first lead in five games. 
It lasted an inning. DeSclafani walked pitcher Jon Lester, a .051 hitter, with two outs in the third after getting ahead. Kyle Schwarber , the Middletown kid, singled. That made him 10-for-21 at Great American. 
Austin Jackson hit one to the wall in right-center to get both runners home and make it 2-1. 
"I was feeling good up to the point (with Lester)," DeSclafani said. "I think I was trying to get a little greedy, going for the punch-out. Then I fall behind the guy, all the sudden I walk him. Things kind of spiraled there. I kind of hit a wall going into the next inning. I couldn't finish the game the way I wanted to." 
The Cubs added one run in the third and one in the fourth to make it 4-1. 
Starlin Castro made it 5-1 in the sixth with his 11 th home run. 
The Cubs turned it into a blowout in the eighth with three runs off Tony Cingrani . Cingrani has allowed seven runs over 4 1/3 innings in his last five appearances. 
Lester got on a roll after the first. After Brayan Pena's double with one out in the second, Lester retired the final 20 batters he faced. 
"You've got to compete better than we competed here in September," Price said. "It's been miserable to watch. I'm sure the players feel the same way I do."
